head.title: Lessons From the Jobs of Summer

hedline.hl1: Lessons From the Jobs of Summer

abstract.p: Jack Devine letter responds to June 18 front-page article on young people's reluctance to take summer jobs; notes traditional summer jobs now eschewed by college students are increasingly filled by immigrants; drawing

block.p: Traditional summer jobs, like lifeguard and waitress, that American college students now eschew are increasingly being filled by foreigners (front page, June 18).
In Ocean City, N.J., boardwalk stores and rides are often staffed by students from Bulgaria, and jobs like landscaping and trash collection are performed by a growing pool of Mexican labor.
Traditional summer jobs, like lifeguard and waitress, that American college students now eschew are increasingly being filled by foreigners (front page, June 18).
In Ocean City, N.J., boardwalk stores and rides are often staffed by students from Bulgaria, and jobs like landscaping and trash collection are performed by a growing pool of Mexican labor.
Paradoxically, the city has become rich in the international complexity American students are seeking elsewhere through semester-abroad programs and internships.
JACK DEVINE Ocean City, N.J., June 18, 2000
